What is evidently a first draft of the above, containing about one-half of the text, is among the Hutchinson papers in possession of the Massachusetts Historical Society, and was printed in its collections, 3rd ser., v. 1, p. 93-101; the handwriting is not that of Mather.

The "Brief relation" includes in addition the 12th article of the Declaration of the gentlemen, merchants, and inhabitants of Boston, Apr. 18, 1689 (believed to have been written by Mather); Abraham Kick's letter to the Princess of Orange, Feb. 1, 1689 n.s.; and a translation of Mather's "De successu Evangelij apud Indos in Nova-Anglia epistola. Ad ... Johannem Leusaenum." It was reprinted in Force's Tracts, v. 4, no. 11, and Andros tracts, v. 2, p. 147-170, the latter containing a discussion of authorship.

div.p: A BRIEF RELATION OF THE STATE OF New England, From the Beginning of that PLANTATION To this Pre≈øent Year, 1689.

p.hi: In a Letter to a Per≈øon of Quality.

div.p: LICENCED, July 30th. 1689.
LONDON, Printed for Richard Baldwine, near the Black Bull in the Old-Baily, 1689.

div.head: A BRIEF RELATION OF THE STATE OF New England.
div.p: I Have received yours, wherein you de≈øire me to give you a Brief Account of the pa≈øt and pre≈øent State of New England, which in as few words as I can, and as ≈øtraits of time will permit me, I ≈øhall endeavour your Satisfaction in.

New England contains that Tract of Land which is between forty and forty five Degrees of Northern Latitude; It was for ≈øome time known by the name of the Northern Plantation; but King Charles the Fir≈øt (then Prince of Wales) gave it the name of New England.
The fir≈øt ≈øettlement of the Engli≈øh there, was in the year 1620, viz. at New Plymouth.

New England differs from other Foreign Plantations, in re≈øpect of the Grounds and Motives, inducing the Fir≈øt Planters to remove
into that American De≈øert; other Plantations were built upon Worldly Intere≈øts, New England upon that which is purely Religious; for although they did, and do agree (as is evident from their Printed Confe≈ø≈øion of Faith) with all other Protestant Reformed Churches; and more e≈øpecially with England, in Matters of Doctrin, and in all Fundamental Points of Faith; yet as to the Liturgy, Ceremonies, and Church-Government by Bi≈øhops, they were, and are Non-conformi≈øts: It was grievous to them to think of living in continual difference with their Prote≈øtant Brethren in England; upon which account they re≈øolved on a peaceable SECESSION into a corner of the World; and being de≈øirous to be under the Protection of England, about twenty worthy Gentlemen obtained a Charter from King Charles the Fir≈øt, bearing date from the year 1628. which giveth them Right to the Soil, for they hold their Titles of Lands, as of the Mannor of Ea≈øt-Greenwich in Kent, and in Common SOCAGE, which, notwith≈øtanding, they purcha≈øed their Lands of the Indians, who were the Native Proprietors: By their mentioned Charter, they are Empower'd to Elect yearly their own Governor, and Deputy-Governor, and Magi≈øtrates, as here in London, and in other Towns Corporate, the Freemen chu≈øe their Lord Mayors, Mayors, Aldermen, &c.

They have al≈øo Power to make ≈øuch Laws, as ≈øhall be mo≈øt proper and ≈øuitable for the Plantation: Neverthele≈øs, as an acknowledgment of their dependance on England, by their Charters, they are obliged not to make any Laws, which ≈øhall be repugnant to the Laws in England.
Al≈øo, the fifth part of all Oar, of Gold or Silver, found in that Territory, belongs to the Crown of England.

The Report of this Charter, did encourage many very de≈øerving per≈øons to Tran≈øplant them≈øelves, and their Families, into New England; Gentlemen of Ancient and Wor≈øhipful Families, and Mini≈øters of the Go≈øpel, then of great fame here in England, Trade≈ømen, Artificers, and Planters, to the Number of about four thou≈øand did in twelve years time go thither.

The hazards they run, and the difficulties which they encountred with, in ≈øubduing a Wilderne≈øs, cannot be ea≈øily expre≈øt in a large Tract: But the Almighty God, by a wonderful Providence, carried them through all.

In the year 1637, they were in imminent danger of being cut off by the barbarous Heathen; but when it came to a War, mighty numbers of the Indians were ≈ølain, by a few of the Engli≈øh, which cau≈øed a terror of God to fall upon the Heathen round about; ≈øo that after the Pequod Indians were ≈øubdued, there was peace in the Land for forty eight years together; and being ≈øetled under a good and ea≈øie Government, the Plantation increa≈øed, and pro≈øpered wonderfully; yea, ≈øo as cannot be parallelled in any Hi≈øtory: never was place brought to ≈øuch a Con≈øiderablene≈øs in ≈øo ≈øhort a time; that which was, not long ≈øince, a howling Wilderne≈øs, in few years time, became a plea≈øant Land, wherein was abundance of all things meet for Soul and Body, which can be imputed to nothing el≈øe, but to their Religion, the Go≈øpel bringing a fulne≈øs of Ble≈ø≈øings along with it: Some have ob≈øerved, that ≈øince the year 1640, more Per≈øons have removed out of New England, than have gone thither. Neverthele≈øs, the four thou≈øand, who did, between that and the year 1620, tran≈øplant them≈øelves into New England, are ≈øo marvelou≈øly increa≈øed, as that, if the Computation fail not, they are now become more than Two hundred thou≈øand Souls.
There are Towns and Villages, on the Sea-Coa≈øts, from Long I≈øland to Bo≈øton, which is Three hundred Engli≈øh Miles, and the like from Bo≈øton to Pemmaquid, which is Two hundred Miles more.

In the year 1662, Conecticot Colony, as al≈øo Read I≈øland, with the Plantations thereunto belonging, had Charters granted to them by King Charles the Second, being much of the ≈øame Tenor with the Patent of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets, whereby the≈øe Colonies were made di≈øtinct Government.
In the year 1675, the Indians began a ≈øecond War with the Engli≈øh; the I≈ø≈øue of which was, that whole Nations of them were de≈øtroy'd.

Never did men ≈øhew greater Courage and Bravery in their Encounters with the Barbarous Heathen, than they did. Although it mu≈øt be acknowledged that the Indians advantages were ≈øuch, as they could not have been overcome, if God had not fought again≈øt them, by ≈øending the Evil Arrows of Famine, and Mortal Di≈øea≈øes among them. I have often thought of an Expre≈ø≈øion of
an Indian there: We could ea≈øily be too hard for the Engli≈øh, but (≈øaid he? ≈øtriking on his Brea≈øt) The Engli≈øhmens God makes us afraid here.

As long as they enjoyed their fir≈øt Government, no Enemies could ≈øtand before them; but ≈øince that they have not been able to ≈øubdue an hundred Indians, who did the la≈øt year commit ≈øome outrages among them, having been (as I am credibly in≈øormed) de≈øignedly provoked thereunto by ≈øome Injuries done unto them by tho≈øe then in Power, who intended the Ruine of the Engli≈øh, and Advancement of the French Intere≈øt in that Territory.

As for your Enquiry, By what means they came to be deprived of their Charters, Rights and Liberties; plea≈øe to under≈øtand, that in the year 1683, a Quo Warranto was i≈ø≈øued out again≈øt them, and with the Notification thereof by the then King's Order there was a Declaration publi≈øhed, enjoyning tho≈øe few particular Per≈øons mentioned in the Quo Warranto, to make their defence at their own perticular Charge, without any help by a publick Stock: By this it was ea≈øie to ≈øee that ≈øome Per≈øons were re≈øolv'd to have the Charters condemned, quo jure quaque injuria: Neverthele≈øs, the Governor and Company appointed an Attorney to appear, and an≈øwer to the Quo Warranto, in the Court of King's Bench.
The Pro≈øecutors not being able to make any thing of it there, a new Suit was Commenced by a Scire facias, in the High Court of Chancery.

But tho they had not ≈øufficient time given them to make their Defence, yet Judgment was entred again≈øt them for Default in not appearing; when it was impo≈ø≈øible, con≈øidering the remote di≈øtance of New England from Westmin≈øter-hall, that they ≈øhould appear in the time allowed.

Thus illegally was the Charter of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets Colony wre≈øted from them: as for the Colonies of Plymouth, Conecticot, and Road I≈øland, there was never any Judgment again≈øt them, nor any Surrender; but by a mere Rape, in the year 1686, their Charters and Priviledges were violently taken from them.

Since that time the Country hath mightily declined, and gone to ruin daily, not being now like the place it was Five Years ago, which is not much to be wondred at, con≈øidering the Intollerable
Oppre≈ø≈øions they have been Labouring under, ≈øince their Charters were Ravi≈øhed from them.

In the Year 1686. Sir Edmond Andros, was ≈øent by the late King James to New England; with a Commi≈ø≈øion ab≈øolutely de≈øtructive to the fundamentals of the Engli≈øh Government, Impowering him with Four more (none of them cho≈øen by the People) to Levy Money, and make Laws, nay, and in ca≈øe of War in the Plantations to ≈øend as many of the Inhabitants as he would, two Thou≈øand Miles out of the Country: This Commi≈ø≈øion being Illegal and ≈øo in it ≈øelf void, the People not being able to Continue longer under tho≈øe Oppre≈ø≈øions, did this la≈øt Spring a≈ø≈øert their Engli≈øh Liberties, Rights and Priviledges, and Unanimou≈øly Declare for the Prince of Orange, and the Parliament of England.

And it is greatly to be ob≈øerved, that as long as New England enjoyed their Charters for more than Fifty Years together, they never put the Crown of England to a Penny Charge; which is more than can be ≈øaid of any other Forreign Plantations dependant on England.
But ≈øince they have been under a Government not by Charters, but by Commi≈ø≈øion, the Country hath been Chargeable, and le≈øs Beneficial to the Kings Revenue than in former times.

It hath indeed been objected, that in New England they did many Years a go Tran≈øgre≈øs the Act of Navigation. But the Tra≈øgre≈ø≈øion of ≈øome few particular Per≈øons ought not to be charged as the fault of the Government there, who did in the Year 1663, make a Law that the Act of Navigation ≈øhould be Strictly ob≈øerved, and their Governours are Sworn to ≈øee that Law Executed, and have to the uttermo≈øt of their power been careful therein.

Many other Things have been ≈øugge≈øted again≈øt New England, he mo≈øt of which having no foot≈øteps of Truth in them, but being the Malicious Inventions of the Tobijahs and Sanballats of the Age, are not worth mentioning.

Not but the People there being but Men, have had their failings as well as other Men in all places of the World. The only thing (≈øo far as I can learn) which can with any Coluor of Truth be ju≈øtly reflected on them as a great fault, is that in ≈øome matters relating to Con≈øcience and difference of opinion, they have been more rigid and ≈øevere than the Primitive Chri≈øtians or the Go≈øpel doth allow of.
Yet this is to be ≈øaid in their behalf, that things are reported wor≈øe than indeed they were, and that now many Leading Men, and the generality of the People are of a more moderate Temper.
I know many that have a great Intere≈øt there, do abhor the Spirit of Per≈øecution as much as any Men in the World.

It is certainly for the Intere≈øt of England, that New England be incouraged; and pre≈øerved in all their Rights, Priviledges and Properties, and tho≈øe ill Men who have given or ≈øhall give contrary advice (notwith≈øtanding all their vain pretences to the contrary) have and will prejudice the Intere≈øt of the Crown more than they are, or ever were, or can be able to make amends for: which I evince by the Arguments following.

list.item:
I. The Kings Revenue, all things con≈øidered, is as much or more augmented by New England, than by any other of the Foreign Plantations. This will ≈øeem to ≈øome a ≈øtrange A≈ø≈øertion: But con≈øider what I ≈øay, and then judge if it be not true.
The other American Plantations cannot well ≈øub≈øi≈øt without New England; which is by a Thou≈øand Leagues nearer to them than either England, or Ireland; ≈øo that they are ≈øupplied with Provi≈øions, Beef, Pork, Meal, Fi≈øh, &c. And al≈øo with the Lumber Trade, Deal Boards, Pipe-Staves, &c. chiefly from New England.
Al≈øo the Carribbe I≈ølands have theire Hor≈øes from thence. It is then in a greater part by means of New England that the other Plantations are made pro≈øperous and beneficial; they pay Cu≈øtoms in the Plantations for the Goods they Export from thence into New England, and when tho≈øe Goods are brought into England, they pay the ≈øame again the Second time, by which means not a little is contributed to the Crown.
Some Manufactures there are among≈øt them, but not a Twentieth part of what the Country hath need of, or is con≈øumed there, mo≈øt of their Cloathing as to Woollen and Linnen, all ≈øorts of Uphol≈øtery Wares, Haberda≈øhers and Silk Wares, Stuffs, Silks, &c. they have from England; and make returns in Plate, Pieces of Eight, Beaver, Moo≈øe and Deer Skins, Oyl, and Iron, all which, but the Bullion, the Country affords.
Al≈øo by Sugars and Tobacco, Indico, and indeed all the Product
of the other Plantations, which with their own Ve≈ø≈øels they fetch and tran≈øport to England.

II. I know not whether in the World there be a better place for ≈øhipping, nor can I ≈øay how many, (but many hundreds there are) hundreds of Ve≈ø≈øels of their own building do belong to the Country, (be≈øides great Numbers built and ≈øold into England,) for they yearly build many good Ships, ≈øome of which for London, and other places in England.
The Country abounds with Pine-Trees, Excellent Cedars, and Oak for building of Ships, and Ship-Ma≈øts in abundance; by tho≈øe that are proper Judges, the be≈øt in the World, and come yearly from thence for the U≈øe of the King's Ships.
And it hath been affirmed by knowing Men in Navigation and Building, that whenever the King of England plea≈øes, he may in New England on ≈øuch ea≈øie Rates as is ≈øcarce imaginable, build Navies of Ships: There being no better Timber in the World, and in ≈øuch quantities as are inexhau≈øtible, and in ≈øuch convenient Places, as if God and Nature had adapted the≈øe va≈øt Timbers for the ≈øaid u≈øe; which is worth con≈øideration, for that Timber is generally wanting in England, and in Ireland; what is, is too far from Waters and Places fit for Carriage, and the Ea≈øt-Land Oak is ≈øpungy and unfit.

III. The Engli≈øh born in New England, have the true inherent Spirit of the Old, apt and fit for Martial Employs; and as an addition to their Natural Courage and Sobriety, are well in≈øtructed in Martial Di≈øcipline.

div.p: All the Inhabitants from ≈øixteen to ≈øixty Years in each Town, are by the Law and con≈øtant Cu≈øtom of the Country to bear Arms, if occa≈øion ≈øhall require, and that they may be fit ≈øo to do,

They have in each Town and Village their Training-days, eight Times every Year, wherein they are exerci≈øed in Military Di≈øcipline, that ≈øo they may be expert in War, on all occa≈øions, for their own Defence, and Service of their Prince; who will find whenever he ≈øhall plea≈øe for to command, and commi≈ø≈øionate them, that they are able (by the Ble≈ø≈øing of God) to ≈øecure and enlarge his Dominions, and to bring
their French Neighbours into an intire Subjection to the Crown of England.

And from this Con≈øideration it was, that the French Mini≈øters, (who all the World knows had a mighty A≈øcendent over White-Hall, in the Two Late Kings Reigns) cea≈øed not in their Negotiations, until among≈øt other Articles agreed on; One was, that in Ca≈øe of a War betwixt England and France, there ≈øhall be a Neutrality in the Plantations: They wi≈øely fore≈øeeing, that if the King of England, ≈øhould arm and commi≈ø≈øion his Subjects in New England, the Frenchmen in tho≈øe parts could not ≈øtand before them.

In the Time of the Late Protector Cromwel, they did by order from England, take ≈øeveral Forts from the French, which by King Charles the Second were re≈øtored to them again; no ways to the Honour or Intere≈øt of the Engli≈øh Nation.

And it's hoped, His Maje≈øty and the High Court of Parliament, will put that value upon New England, as ≈øo va≈øt a Tract of Land and Body of People de≈øerve from a Government on which they depend, and are ≈øo great and u≈øeful a Member, as they have manife≈øted them≈øelves to be: And that in ≈øo Eminent a manner as calls for Protection, Encouragement, and Re≈øtauration to all their Rights, Priviledges and Proprieties, and what Additions more, as in His Maje≈øty great Wi≈ødom, ≈øhall be thought fit for his Service, the Prote≈øtant Religion and the good of that People; who on the 18th. of April, 1689. Unanimou≈øly ro≈øe in Arms, and after having ≈øeized upon their Illegal Governour, and the re≈øt of their Oppre≈ø≈øors; declared for the Prince of Orange, and the Parliament of England, the Prote≈øtant Religion and their Ancient Con≈øtitution, and to this day do keep the Country for our Pre≈øent Sovereigns, King William and Queen Mary, again≈øt King Lewis, and the Abdicated King James, waiting His Maje≈øties Commands, &c.

Which Declaration is in the words following: WE do therefore ≈øeize upon the Per≈øons of tho≈øe few Ill Men, which have (been next unto our
≈øins) the Grand Authors of our Mi≈øeries, re≈øolving to ≈øecure them, for what Ju≈øtice, Orders from his Highne≈øs, with the Engli≈øh Parliament ≈øhall direct, le≈øt, e're we are aware, we find (what we may fear, being on all ≈øides in danger) our ≈øelves to be by them given away to a Foreign Power, before ≈øuch Orders can reach unto us, for which Orders we now humbly wait; in the mean time firmly believing, that we have endeavoured nothing but what meer Duty to God and our Country calls for at our hands: We commit our Enterprize to the Ble≈ø≈øing of him, who hears the Cry of the oppre≈ø≈øed, and advi≈øe all our Neighbours for whom we have thus ventured our ≈øelves, to joyn with us in Prayers, and all ju≈øt Actions for the Defence of the Land.

The twelfth Article of New England is the Key of the New World America; if the French King had got it into his Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, he might ≈øoon have made him≈øelf Ma≈øter of America, and this in all Probability would have been done this Summer, if the New Englanders in and about Bo≈øton, penetrating into the De≈øigns carrying on, had not ri≈øen as one Man, and ≈øeized Sir E. A. (who is as of a French Extract, ≈øo in the French Intere≈øts; being ≈øent to New England by the Late King James, with an Illegal and Arbitrary Commi≈ø≈øion) and tho≈øe ill Men who joyned with him in his Tyranny.

All men do acknowledge, that tho≈øe brave Souls whom God hath ≈øo wonderfully a≈ø≈øi≈øted, and ≈øpirited to pre≈øerve London-Derry, (and perhaps thereby to ≈øave all Ireland) by ≈øecuring it, and declaring for King William and Queen Mary, de≈øerve great Favour and Protection from the Government.

And the ≈øame mu≈øt be acknowledged due unto the People of New England, and more e≈øpecially, when it is con≈øidered of what Value and Con≈øequence to England, New England is, and that they ≈øo early as it were, re≈øcued the Country out of the hands of the French, even before they knew the Prince of Orange was King of England, and that at a Time when they
knew no more, than that His Highne≈øs was landed in England, with a de≈øign to endeavour the delivering the Kingdom, and the Churches of God from Popery, Slavery and Arbitrary Power, which as they lookt upon as an Heroick and Glorious Undertaking; ≈øo they al≈øo accounted it their Duty to embark them≈øelves in the ≈øame Cau≈øe; though they knew not what the I≈ø≈øue of ≈øo mighty a Work would be; which hath cau≈øed ≈øome Per≈øons of no Mean Figure to ≈øay,
The≈øe People de≈øerve His Maje≈øties and the Nations Re≈øpect, Countenance, and Speedy Re≈øtitution of all their Rights, and to be enabled by His Maje≈øties Commi≈ø≈øions to pro≈øecute the War again≈øt France in America, which they are capable to do without any con≈øiderable Charge to the Government.
And indeed New England, hath upon the be≈øt Accounts which can be mentioned, out-done all America.

For there they have erected an ∆≤niver≈øity, which began in the year 1642, wherein things are managed, pro more Academiarum in Anglia: Several Per≈øons of more than ordinary Learning; yea, and many ≈øcores of able Mini≈øters, of the Go≈øpel, have there had their Education.
There by the Statutes of the Colledge, none is to be admitted, before he can write Latin in a pure Style, and tran≈ølate any ordinary Greek Author.
It is cu≈øtomary with them, every Morning in the Colledge-Hall, to read a Chapter out of the Hebrew Bible, and at Night a Chapter out of the Greek Original.

The Tutors there in≈øtruct their Pupils in Logick, Natural and Moral Philo≈øophy, Metaphy≈øicks, Geography, A≈øtronomy, Arithmetick, Geometry, &c. and the Learned Men there have a corre≈øponding communication with other Learned Men in divers parts of the World, where the Reformed Religion is profe≈ø≈øed, and by them highly reverenced for their Learning and Sobriety; an In≈øtance of which appears by the following Letter, written by the Eminent Mr. Kick, to the Queen's Maje≈øty that now is, in February la≈øt, by way of Supplication for New England.

body.head: To Her Royal Highne≈øs the Prince≈øs of Orange, &c.

opener.salute: May it plea≈øe your Royal Highne≈øs,

THE great and good God, who

Nay, I will be bold to ≈øay, that New England hath out-done the whole World; for among the Indians, who a while ≈øince were mere Heathens, there are not only many Congregations of them, who are converted to the Chri≈øtian Faith, and the Prote≈øtant (which is the only True) Religion: But no le≈øs than Four and twenty of tho≈øe Heathens, are now not only Chri≈øtians, but Preachers of the Go≈øpel of Je≈øus Chri≈øt. Thus Sir I have endeavoured to gratifie your reque≈øt with as much Brevity as the Subject will admit, and exceeding the Bounds of a Letter, am forced to be ≈øo prolix, and the rather for that mo≈øt of what I have written is upon my own knowledge, Truth (and the re≈øt undeniable fact) though not the twentieth Part of the Truths might be ≈øaid of the Almighty's mo≈øt wonderful ble≈ø≈øing and pro≈øpering New England, and his Go≈øpel among the Heathen there, which to me looks like the Beginnings of the fulfilling tho≈øe many Prophecies in Holy Writ concerning them.
